Description: Painted wooden model group: a peasant farmer wearing only a linen kilt, typical dress for a field worker, guides a team of two speckled oxen who draw a simple wooden plow which would have had a metal blade. He pushes down strongly on the handle and has sunk up to his ankles in the freshly turned moist soil.
Curator's comments: Wooden models of this type depicting workers involved in various forms of food production were placed in the tombs of provincial noblemen and high officials, from the time of the end of the Old Kingdom onwards to provide the deceased by magical means with all the requirements of the afterlife. Thus, they supplement the depiction of food and drink production on contemporary tomb walls. In this instance, the model ensured the tomb owner would never lack for grain in the other world from which to make bread and beer, two of the staples of the Egyptian diet. Bibliography: D.
